title: Serval and The Formula
statementHtml:
You are given two positive integers xx and yy (1≤x,y≤1091≤x,y≤109).

Find a non-negative integer k≤1018k≤1018, such that (x+k)+(y+k)=(x+k)⊕(y+k)(x+k)+(y+k)=(x+k)⊕(y+k) holds∗∗, or determine that such an integer does not exist.

∗∗⊕⊕ denotes the bitwise XOR operation.
inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

The only line of each test case contains two integers xx and yy (1≤x,y≤1091≤x,y≤109) — the given integers.
outputSpecHtml:
For each test case, output a single integer kk (0≤k≤10180≤k≤1018) — the integer you found. Print −1−1 if it is impossible to find such an integer.

If there are multiple answers, you may print any of them.
noteHtml:
In the first test case, since (2+0)+(5+0)=(2+0)⊕(5+0)=7(2+0)+(5+0)=(2+0)⊕(5+0)=7, k=0k=0 is a possible answer. Note that k=4k=4 is also a possible answer because (2+4)+(5+4)=(2+4)⊕(5+4)=15(2+4)+(5+4)=(2+4)⊕(5+4)=15.

In the second test case, (x+k)⊕(y+k)=(6+k)⊕(6+k)=0(x+k)⊕(y+k)=(6+k)⊕(6+k)=0. However, (x+k)+(y+k)>0(x+k)+(y+k)>0 holds for every k≥0k≥0, implying that such an integer kk does not exist.
